awd_titl_txt: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Assessing evolution of euryhalinity in anchialine shrimps
awd_abstract_narration:
The molecular mechanisms of ionic/salt regulation in crustaceans have only been characterized for a narrow range of species, mainly crabs with a marine ancestry. Shrimp from coastal ponds and pools represent an opportunity to address this lack of knowledge since they have a decisively freshwater ancestry but have adapted to live in environments with drastically fluctuating salinities. Previous research found that Halocaridina rubra, a shrimp species endemic to Hawaii, has atypical patterns of gene expression following salinity transfer. To examine this in an evolutionary context, the molecular mechanisms of osmoregulation from additional shrimp species from the Ryukyus Islands, Japan will be investigated using high-throughput measures of gene expression (RNA-Seq). These shrimp species represent independent invasions of these habitats (from both freshwater and marine environments) and will further our limited understanding of the evolution of osmoregulation in crustaceans.

Overall, this project will illuminate the evolution of osmoregulation, a critical biological process for all living organisms. Undergraduates from underrepresented groups will be trained and mentored during the project. Additionally, this system will be used to engage K-12 students in a variety of biological concepts.

por.por_cntn:
The molecular mechanisms of ionic/salt regulation in crustaceans (i.e., osmoregulation) have only been characterized for a narrow range of species, mainly crabs with a marine ancestry. Shrimps from anchialine habitats (coastal ponds and pools) represent an opportunity to address this lack of knowledge since they have a decisively freshwater ancestry but have adapted to live in these "extreme" environments characterized by drastically fluctuating salinities. Previous research found that the Hawaiian endemic atyid Halocaridina rubra has atypical patterns of gene expression following salinity transfer. Specifically, genes typically and dramatically up-regulated (~100 fold) during salinity transfer in other crustaceans do not change significantly in H. rubra. However, no published studies have examined the molecular mechanisms of osmoregulation or functional evolution of anchialine shrimp species.

 

To examine this in an evolutionary context, the molecular mechanisms of osmoregulation from additional anchialine shrimp species from the Ryukyus Islands, Japan were investigated using high-throughput measures of gene expression (RNA-Seq). These species represent lineages of varying relatedness to H. rubra, many of which have independently invaded anchialine habitats either from seawater or freshwater habitats. A wide range of gene expression responses to salinity was identified among even closely-related anchialine shrimp species. For example, up-regulation of genes not previously implicated in osmoregulation was found in H. rubra. In the Japanese species, responses varied, with some appearing to behave like previously studied crustaceans. These results suggest that anchialine shrimps have several different molecular mechanisms for coping with the variable salinity regimes found in anchialine habitats. This project illuminates the evolution of osmoregulation, a critical biological process for all living organisms, including humans.

 

Broader impacts of this award, in conjunction with a NSF EAPSI fellowship (IIA# 1309694), included providing the awardee a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction on to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of Japan; and an orientation to Japanese society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to cultivate international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce. Furthermore, undergraduates from underrepresented groups in the sciences were trained and mentored during this project. Additionally, this project fostered research collaborations between scientists at Auburn University and Oregon State University. The experiences gained from this award were presented to the scientific and general public through presentations at scientific meetings and peer-reviewed publications. Lastly, anchialine habitats and organisms were used to engage K-12 students in a variety of biological concepts.
